meanings.definition: A situation in which you must choose between two things that are opposite or cannot be had at the same time
meanings.sent1: Making a tradeoff between studying for the test and going to the party is difficult.
meanings.sent2: The tradeoff between saving money and buying a new phone is a common dilemma.
meanings.sent3: I faced a tradeoff between eating the last cookie and saving it for later.
meanings.sent4: Life is full of tradeoffs, like balancing work and personal time.
meanings.sent5: The tradeoff between sleep and finishing the project was tough to decide.

meanings.definition: The act of giving up one thing in return for another
meanings.sent1: She made a tradeoff by giving up dessert to have a healthier meal.
meanings.sent2: His tradeoff of free time for extra work paid off in the end.
meanings.sent3: The tradeoff of missing the movie was worth it for the concert.
meanings.sent4: Sometimes a tradeoff of short-term gain leads to long-term benefits.
meanings.sent5: Making a tradeoff between comfort and style is a common fashion dilemma.

meanings.definition: An exchange of one thing for another of more or less equal value
meanings.sent1: The tradeoff of my old phone for a new one was a good decision.
meanings.sent2: In business, tradeoffs are often necessary for successful negotiations.
meanings.sent3: I made a tradeoff of my time for a chance to learn a new skill.
meanings.sent4: The tradeoff of trading cards with a friend was fair and enjoyable.
meanings.sent5: Finding the right tradeoff between cost and quality is important when shopping.
